awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations in Conservation Laws and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project is devoted to developing new mathematical methods and techniques for studying some nonlinear partial differential equations governing the fluid flow and related applications. Their study is crucial for understanding the dynamics of many applications critical for STEM including gas dynamics, engineering, materials science, geometry, fluid turbulence, shell theory, active systems in biology/biophysics, stochastic dynamics, and so on. While the one-dimensional problems are rather well understood, the general theory for the multi-dimensional case is mathematically underdeveloped. The research project will advance knowledge of the fundamental areas of mathematics and mechanics as well as applications; it will also provide opportunities for students, including those from underrepresented groups and women, to receive training in these important areas through participation in the active research in applied mathematics. 

The goal of the project is to investigate some nonlinear partial differential equations arising from multi-dimensional conservation laws and related applications. The research program focuses on the following topics:
(1) the existence and stability of transonic contact discontinuity in gas dynamics:  this is a free boundary and mixed-type problem, and this study will provide new methods and shed light on the general multi-dimensional theory of conservation laws;
(2) the global smooth solutions to the Gauss-Codazzi equations of isometric immersion of surfaces: a global smooth solution to the Gauss-Codazzi equations yields a smooth isometric immersion of surfaces, and it is challenging to find such a global smooth solution for general surfaces;
(3) the weak and strong solutions to the stochastic compressible Navier-Stokes equations with various types of noise: the stochastic problems for the compressible flows are underdeveloped and widely open, and many fundamental problems are difficult; and
(4) global solutions to the system of active hydrodynamics in biology: active systems arise in many practical applications in biology/biophysics, and its modeling and analysis are challenging due to its complexity, while fundamental mathematical problems are widely open.
The purpose of this research is to develop novel analytic methods and efficient techniques for solving some important problems in multi-dimensional inviscid and viscous compressible flows and applications, and to gain insights into the general multi-dimensional problems of conservation laws and emerging real-world applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on the PDE problems in fluid dynamics and related applications. During the project period, the following problems were studied, novel analytic methods and efficient techniques were developed, and new and significant results were obtained:

(1) Stability of supersonic and transonic contact discontinuities for two-dimensional steady compressible Euler flows in a finitely long nozzle.

(2) Linear and nonlinear stability of compressible vortex sheets in 2D and 3D elastodynamics, including the isentropic and non-isentropic cases.

(3) Vanishing viscosity limit to the planar rarefaction wave for the multi-dimensional compressible Navier-Stokes equations.

(4) Magnetic effects on the solvability of the two-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic boundary layer equations without resistivity in Sobolev spaces.

(5) Energy equality in compressible fluids with physical boundaries; a Kato-type criterion for vanishing viscosity near the Onsager's critical regularity.

(6) Global regularity of the three-dimensional fractional micropolar equations.

(7) Large time behavior and diffusion limit for a system of balance laws from chemotaxis in multi-dimensions; Cauchy problem of a system of parabolic conservation laws arising from the singular Keller-Segel model in multi-dimensions.

(8) Global well-posedness and optimal large-time behavior of strong solutions to the multi-dimensional non-isentropic particle-fluid two phase flows.

(9) Global weak solutions to the stationary Cahn-Hilliard-Navier-Stokes equations for the diffuse interface model of compressible flows.

(10) A rigidity property for the Novikov equation and the asymptotic stability of peakons.

(11) Inviscid limit of compressible viscoelastic equations with the no-slip boundary condition.

The methods and ideas developed in the project can be applied to study other problems in related areas. The mathematical issues addressed in the project are fundamental for the understanding of the dynamics of fluid flows and applications. The research of the project (a) yielded new methods of analysis and efficient techniques for solving some important problems in multi-dimensional conservation laws and applications; (b) provided more insight into the qualitative behavior of flow motion; (c) established new interdisciplinary connections of fluid dynamics and elastodynamics; and (d) likely sheded light and provided important clue of new methods on other multi-dimensional problems of conservation laws and emerging applications.

The research provided new understanding of the mathematics of fluids and gases critical for fluid dynamics, gas dynamics, biology and elastodynamics. The project provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas. In particular, the project provided advanced training for graduate students and allowed their participation in the research of some outstanding problems, via supervising graduate students (including two female students) and organizing workshops and working seminars; and disseminated new research results via the principal investigator's website, publications, mini-courses, and talks in conferences.
